questions.question_text:
An administrator is planning to deploy workloads on a six node vSAN cluster, and all nodes are distributed equally across three racks.
Which action is required to ensure that the workload VMs remain compliant with the default vSAN policy after a complete rack failure?

discussion.content: I have the current questions. I need help for response the questions
d --> the default spbm is assigned which is mirroring
A is correct

comments.content: No way..here is why FTT=1 (erasure coding) is basically RAID 5 and to lose one RACK and be fully complaint with SPBM then you will need minimum of 5 RACKS!! because FTT=1 (erasure coding) requires 4 RACKS minimum in this case or 4 hosts in other cases but if you lose one host or RACK in this case then you are NOT complaint but if you have 5 hosts or RACKS as fault domains then losing one will NOT make it uncompliant. A says 4 Racks hence WRONG and answer is definitely D
the question says "remain compliant with the default vSAN policy " . default vSAN policy is RAID1 FTT1

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is correct

Answer is correct. 
Adding hosts in rack is not changing anything if rack fails - B,C excluded
Erasure coding on 4 fault domains will work if one rack goes down but object will be not compliant

choices.C: Add an additional host per rack, and configure vSAN with three fault domains and FTT=2.
choices.A: Add an additional rack with two hosts, and configure vSAN with four fault domains and FTT=1 (erasure coding).
choices.D: Add an additional rack with two hosts, and configure vSAN with four fault domains and FTT=1 (mirroring).
choices.B: Add two additional hosts per rack, and configure vSAN with three fault domains and FTT=1.

questions.question_text:
A company has deployed a 12-node (6-6-1) vSAN 7.0 stretched cluster for all production workloads.
The customer currently uses four different vSAN storage policies for running the workloads depending on the applications requirements:
✑ Policy 1 - Site Disaster Tolerance=Dual Site Mirroring, FTT=Erasure Coding
✑ Policy 2 - Site Disaster Tolerance=Dual Site Mirroring, FTT=Mirroring
✑ Policy 3 - Site Disaster Tolerance=None - Keep Data on Preferred, FTT=Mirroring
✑ Policy 4 - Site Disaster Tolerance=None - Keep Data on Non-Preferred, FTT=Mirroring
During the setup of the vSAN stretched cluster, the following VM/Host Rules were created:
✑ Preferred Site - Preferred Site workloads should run on DC1 hosts.
✑ Secondary Site - Secondary Site workloads should run on DC2 hosts.
Which two activities should the administrator complete to ensure that there is no impact to production services during the maintenance window in the Preferred
Site? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
I think AE
A : to replicate VMs on second site
E : to move compute for those VMs on second site

Selected Answer: AE
A and E.
A - This is the only policy running the VMs unprotected in DC1, so you'd want to change it to be mirrored to the other site.
E - You could always have DRS push the workload to DC2.
AE for me is correct

I also think A,E
D - wrong as no dual site replication is set up 
B - wrong but promissig - should rule will not ensure that VMs are working on secondary site 
C- wrong Policy is enforcing worklads to run in primary only and we dont want this.

choices.B: Update vSphere DRS site affinity rules so that Preferred Site workloads should not run on hosts in DC1.
choices.E: Update vSphere DRS site affinity rules so that Preferred Site workloads must run on hosts in DC2.
choices.D: Change the FTT setting in Policy 3 to be ג€Erasure Codingג€.
choices.C: Change the Site Disaster Tolerance setting in Policy 4 to be ג€None - Keep Data on Preferredג€.
choices.A: Change the Site Disaster Tolerance setting in Policy 3 to be ג€Dual Site Mirroringג€.

questions.question_text:
An administrator is tasked with preparing for a Cross vCenter migration in a stretched vSAN cluster where the virtual machines migration will be orchestrated via
VMware Site Recovery Manager.
Which action should the administrator take so the migration is successful?

choices.C: Enable vCenter Single Sign-On Enhanced Linked Mode
choices.D: Make sure that Witness traffic is on the management NIC.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
"Stretched storage is supported only on vCenter Single Sign-On Enhanced Linked Mode environments."

C is correct as per
https://docs.vmware.com/en/Site-Recovery-Manager/8.5/com.vmware.srm.admin.doc/GUID-B64096E8-F49A-4BF6-92CE-05FBA972F3C0.html

Stretched storage is supported only on vCenter Single Sign-On Enhanced Linked Mode environments. Planned migration with Cross vCenter Server vMotion fails if the sites are not Enhanced Linked Mode. Stretched storage is required when using Cross vCenter Server vMotion during a planned migration.

one host can run up to 200 VMs - so what with MM, any failure ?
Cluster should be sized with 6 ESXi hosts minumim 
Also cache should be 10% of raw HDD storage - before RAID policies applied. So what RAID 0? What architect is mentioned in this question? I belive learning one :D :D

Selected Answer: C
in vsan 7 you can only use disk with 600gb max size
C. The Cache disk size is capped at 600GB in 7.0. Even if you use a bigger disk, only 600GB of it will be used. https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/89485

Doesn't change the answer to this question but in 7.0, the usable Cache disk size is 600GB, increased to 1.6TB in 8.0

https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/89485

comments.content: I would agree, you should aim for 10% caching minimum. However, there is the 600GB maximum to consider. There is an option to go beyond that with v8, at additional overhead (RAM per node). As they expect to grow, I would install 800GB disks with only 600 usable. Once they grow beyond the 600 machines, enable the option to go beyond that and accept the additional overhead.

discussion.content: D for sure cache 10% of total node capacity and hence 8000GB = 800GD SSD cache
